events.title: Naval Forces Adjust as ABDIEL Evacuates Wounded Amidst Kaso Strait Withdrawal
events.description: : . 25th May, to4r. ' 59. The naval situation at daylight on the ‘25th “May was:— : (2) ABDIEL had left Suda at 0240 with some 60 walking wounded. and was on her + + way back to Alexaridria. . . : ‘ {(b) The force with AJAX had sighted . nothing to the north of Crete. Thére was no . time to out’ the ‘bombardment of :..’ Maleme, so the force was now withdrawing ,through the Kaso Strait. » Th = 58154

events.title: Fleet Air Arm Launches M.A.Q.3 Operation: Strike Against Enemy Aerodrome in Crete
events.description: aerodrome was being “extensively used by the enemy in his operations against Crete. It was, therefore, decided to attack the aerodrome with Fleet Air Arm aircraft* from FORMIDABLE who had now built up her fighter strength to 12 Fulmars, though some of them were of doubtful reliability. Vice Admiral 1st Battle Squadron was given charge of the operation: which was to be known as M.A.Q.3. At 1200 on 25th May, Vice Admiral 1st Battle Squadron in QUEEN ELIZABETH, with BARHAM, FORMIDABLE, JERVIS, JANUS, KANDAHAR, NUBIAN, HASTY, HEREWARD, VOYAGER and VENDETTA (Force A) left Alexandria to carry out.M.A.Q.3.

events.title: Enemy Breaks Through New Line in Maleme-Canea Sector on Crete
events.description: 64. Late that night (25th May) the new line which had been formed in the Maleme—Canea sector in Crete was broken by the enemy, after.

events.title: VENTRY and JAGUAR Depart Alexandria with Troops, Heading to Tymbaki
events.description: VENTRY and JAGUAR had left Alexandria at 2000/25th May and was on her way to Tymbaki, with troops.

events.description: VENTRY and JAGUAR had left Alexandria at 2000/25th May and was on her way to Tymbaki, with troops.

events.title: Queens Regiment Battleground: Conducting Courage Under Heavy Bombing Attacks
events.description: at. 2000/25th May with a Battalion of the Queens Regiment. The force was subjected to ‘bombing’ attacks by reconnaissance aircraft during the forenoon of 26th.May. At x820 there were two ‘heavy dive bombing attacks by aircraft’ formations, and.one appeared to be damaged during these attacks. A final attack by low fiying torpedo

events.title: Naval Forces Mobilize to Foil Possible Night Landing at Sitia
events.description: “of Theré had been indications that a landing might take place at Sitia during the night 24th/a5th. in order to deal with this landing, a force consisting of AJAX (Senior Officer), DIDO, KIMBERLEY, and HOTSPUR left Alexandria at o800 on the 24th May, with. orders ‘to pass .through the Kaso Strait and sweep the north coast of Crete during the night 24th/25th May. If nothing was sighted and time allowed, this force was also to. bombard Maleme aerodrome. .

events.title: Urgent Orders for Northern Norway Evacuation Issued Overnight
events.description: I. On the night of 24/25th May, orders were received for the evacuation of Northern Norway and were contained in following message : —

events.title: Chronicle of Turmoil: Key Events From Late May to June 1940
events.description: General Survey of Events during the Period from 25th May to and June 1940.

events.title: Strategic Delay: Key Operation Postponed for Reinforcements Ahead of Enemy Threat
events.description: 61. The operation was originally intended to take place on the night 24/25th May, but at a conference with General Bethouart on 23rd May I came to the conclusion that unless the weather was very propitious it would be an unjustifiable risk to undertake it with the support of only one fighter squadron of aircraft, in view of the strength and efficiency of the enemy bombers. I decided therefore that it should be postponed until after the arrival of the Hurricane fighter squadron which was due on 27th May. Lord Cork agreed with this decision.

events.title: Command Transition: British Troops in Madagascar Under New Leadership as of July 1, 1942
events.description: “Qn 25th May, 1942, I received instructions that, at a later date, I was to take over command of all British troops in Madagascar. On Ist July, 1942, the occupied area of Madagascar came under my command.

events.title: Fifteenth Air Force Delayed: Targets in Southern France and Germany Remain Untouched Until May 1944
events.description: 58. In addition to these targets, the United States Fifteenth Air Force were allocated fonrteen targets in Southern France and nine targets in Germany. However, this Command did not operate against these targets in Southern France until 25th May, 1944 and then only for three days. The targets allocated to them in Germany were not attacked.

events.title: US Fifteenth Air Force Launches Massive Bombing Campaign, Drops 3,074 Tons on Key Southern France Targets Ahead of D-Day
events.description: 63. In the attacks made by the United States Fifteenth Air Force on 25th May, 1944, and the subsequent two days, 1,600 sorties were flown against 14 targets and 3,074 tons of bombs were dropped. Of these 14 targets allocated in Southern France, at D-Day five were Category “A”, one was Category ‘‘ B ’’ and eight were Category “C*.  *

events.title: Intensified Assaults on Military Installations: 14 Sites Destroyed in Strategic May Offensive
events.description: 105. On roth May, 1944, a series of attacks was begun against the long range aircraft reporting stations, and on 18th May, on the installations used for night fighter control and the control of coastal guns, On 25th May, 42 sites were scheduled for attack. These sites included 106 installations; at D-3, fourteen of these sites were confirmed destroyed.

events.title: Eighth Air Force Fighter Command Strikes: Over 600 Sorties Devastate Enemy Transport in Europe
events.description: 79. On 25th May, United States Eighth Air Force Fighter Command flew 608 sorties over France and Belgium, with the result that 41 locomotives, I troop train with approximately 300 men and 19 trucks were destroyed, and 25 locomotives and 50 trucks were damaged. Though outside the ‘‘ Neptune ”* area, it is interesting to record that on agth May, aircraft of Eighth Air Force Fighter Command flew 571 sorties over Eastern Germany and Poland, attacking 24 locomotives, 32 oil tank cars, ‘16 box cars and 3 freight trains with unobserved results. In addition to these special attacks, aircraft of Eighth Air Force Fighter Command frequently attacked locomotives and trains amongst other ground targets, when returning from escorting heavy bombers.

events.title: Australian Division Readies Advance into Syria Amidst Tactical Dilemma
events.description: go. On 25th May I reported to the War Office that I was preparing a plan for an advance into Syria with the 7th Australian Division less one brigade, the Free French troops, and certain units of the xst Cavalry Division. This was a much smaller force than I considered necessary, also I disliked using the Free French since J knew that this would be likely to stiffen the resistance of the French in Syria, but I had no other troops I could make available. I was instructed by the Chiefs of Staff to advance into Syria as soon as the above force was reasonably prepared. I reported that 7th June.was the earliest date by which the operation could start, actually it began on 8th June.

events.title: Intense Battles Rage as Enemy Troops Advance Near Canea Amid Heavy Bombardment
events.description: 62. On 24th May and 25th May the fighting continued with the same intensity. The enemy continued to land troops and to force back our line fromthe Maleme area towards Canea, which .,was heavily bombed and almost

events.title: BISMARCK's Narrow Escape: A Stealthy Voyage Through British Naval Forces
events.description: 51. The track of the BISMARCK as drawn on the attached strategical plot (see Plan 1) is probably reasonably accurate. It shows how narrowly she avoided contact with the various British forces during her run east. She started by crossing about r00 miles astern of KING GEORGE V at o800 on 25th May and then passed about 50 miles from RODNEY and 45 miles from EDINBURGH. On the next day

events.title: Admiralty Signals Indicate Bismarck Retreating Across Atlantic; Home Fleet Mobilizes for Search
events.description: 52. At 1030 on 25th May, a series of D/F bearings was received from the Admiralty which indicated that the enemy was breaking back across the Atlantic. The signals appeared to some from the same ship which shad transmitted several signals soon after the T/B attack of the night before; they could therefore ° Tteasonably be attributed to the BISMARCK. These bearings, as plotted in KING GEORGE V, showed a position too far to the northward, which gave the misleading impression that the enemy was making for the North Sea. J broadcast this position of the enemy and instructed all Home Fleet forces to search accordingiy. PRINCE OF WALES had not yet joined, but the course of KING GEORGE V was altered to 055°, 27 knots, to make for the IcelandFaeroes gap.

events.title: BISMARCK's Strategic Escape: A Close Call with British Forces During Eastern Run
events.description: 51. The track of the BISMARCK as drawn on the attached strategical plot (see Plan 1) is probably reasonably accurate. It shows how narrowly she avoided contact with the various British forces during her run east. She started by crossing about r00 miles astern of KING GEORGE V at o800 on 25th May and then passed about 50 miles from RODNEY and 45 miles from EDINBURGH. On the next day

events.title: Admiralty Reports Enemy Movements: Misleading Signals Pointing to Bismarck Prompt Search by Home Fleet
events.description: 52. At 1030 on 25th May, a series of D/F bearings was received from the Admiralty which indicated that the enemy was breaking back across the Atlantic. The signals appeared to some from the same ship which shad transmitted several signals soon after the T/B attack of the night before; they could therefore ° Tteasonably be attributed to the BISMARCK. These bearings, as plotted in KING GEORGE V, showed a position too far to the northward, which gave the misleading impression that the enemy was making for the North Sea. J broadcast this position of the enemy and instructed all Home Fleet forces to search accordingiy. PRINCE OF WALES had not yet joined, but the course of KING GEORGE V was altered to 055°, 27 knots, to make for the IcelandFaeroes gap.

events.title: Intense Search Efforts Underway: Morning of May 25th Sees Heightened Activity
events.description: Search—Morning of 25th May.

events.title: Force 'H' Sets Course to Intercept Bismarck: High-Stakes Naval Maneuver at Dawn
events.description: 2. At 0330 on Sunday, 25th May, Force ““H”? was in position 39° 35’ N. 14° 10’ W., steering 310° at 24 knots. At this time instructions. were received to steer to intercept BISMARCK from the southward. The enemy had last been located in position 56° 30’ N. 36° 00’ W. at 0306 when SUFFOLK lost touch. The’ existing course and speed was therefore maintained.

events.title: Commander-in-Chief's Arrival Delayed: Miscalculation Pushes Timetable to Early Morning May 25th
events.description: (tThis was due to a miscalculation. The earliest the Commander-in-Chief could arrive, even if he forecast exactly the enemy’s movements, was between 0600 and 0700/25th May.)

events.title: Coastal Command Launches Air Patrols in Search of Missing Hipper Class Cruiser PRINZ EUGEN
events.description: As the Hipper class cruiser—PRINZ EUGEN—last seen in company with the BISMARCK early on 25th May was unaccounted for, Coastal Command maintained two patrols by Sunderlands of No. 10 Squadron across the mouth of the Bay of Biscay from dawn during the day, and Hudsons of No.

events.title: Vice-Admiral Sir Takes Command: Force 'H' Sets Sail at Dawn
events.description: 59. At rz00 on 25th May, when in position 4r° 30’ N. 17° 10’ W., the Flag Officer Commanding, Force ‘‘H’’ (Vice-Admiral Sir

events.title: BISMARCK BOMBED: A Timeline of Devastating Hits Amid Naval Warfare
events.description: 88. From the information available, it appears that the BISMARCK suffered three hits by gunfire on 24th May, one hit by aircraft torpedo on 25th May and two on 26th May, two hits by destroyer torpedoes early on

events.title: Strategic Shift: C-in-C Urged to Reject French Somaliland Talks Amid Syrian Tensions
events.description: I wrote to the C-in-C to the above effect on 25th May, and also suggested that if he was in agreement with the policy, all that would now be required would be to inform the Governor of French Somaliland that in view of the situation in Syria he refused to treat with him. *

events.title: Record-Setting Convoy Sets Sail Amidst Danger: 35 Ships Brave Hostile Skies
events.description: 26. P.Q.16, which sailed on 20th May, contained 35 ships and, despite the fact that this was the most unfavourable time of the year, was the largest convoy which had so far been me It was escorted by five destroyers, four ites, four trawlers, one minesweeper and A.A. ship. It was located by enemy aireatan 24th May and, though one shadower was shot down on 25th May by the Hurricane from the C.A.M. ship, was shadowed con-

events.title: High-Stakes Air Assault: Allied Forces Target Enemy Bases, American Ship Damaged in Far-Away Struggle
events.description: 27. The first attack, 380 miles from the enemy aerodromes, was made on 25th May by eight torpedo aircraft and about’ twenty -Ju.88s: one ship, the American s.s. CARLTON, had a steam pipe fractured and turned back for Iceland, in tow of the trawler NORTHERN SPRAY:. one Ju.88 was shot down and four more were probably destroyed.

events.title: Massive Naval Convoy Defies Odds Amidst Enemy Shadows in May Mission
events.description: 26. P.Q.16, which sailed on 20th May, contained 35 ships and, despite the fact that this was the most unfavourable time of the year, was the largest convoy which had so far been me It was escorted by five destroyers, four ites, four trawlers, one minesweeper and A.A. ship. It was located by enemy aireatan 24th May and, though one shadower was shot down on 25th May by the Hurricane from the C.A.M. ship, was shadowed con-

events.title: Fierce Air Assault Strikes 380 Miles from Enemy Bases: U.S. Ship Damaged, Ju.88s Face Heavy Losses
events.description: 27. The first attack, 380 miles from the enemy aerodromes, was made on 25th May by eight torpedo aircraft and about’ twenty -Ju.88s: one ship, the American s.s. CARLTON, had a steam pipe fractured and turned back for Iceland, in tow of the trawler NORTHERN SPRAY:. one Ju.88 was shot down and four more were probably destroyed.

events.title: Looking Back: Insights from April to May 1945 in Continuing Correspondence
events.description: 2. This covers the j period from the 23rd April to 25th May, 1945, and is in continuation of my letter of 7th. June, 1945.

events.title: Fleet Prepares for July Operations Following Final Strike on May 25
events.description: considerable amount of work would be required to make good the battle damage to carriers, it appeared desirable to conclude operations with the twelfth strike:day on 25th May,*and so ensure, the Fleet -being ready to resume operations when required in July.

events.title: Elba Captured After Delays: Strategic Operation Completes by Mid-June
events.description: The capture of Elba, early plans for which I have already mentioned, took place about this time. I originally wanted this operation to be Jaunched if possible before the spring offensive opened but it had been postponed to a date between 2oth and 25th May. On 16th May I was informed that it had been further postponed till mid-June. This removed almost all the value of the operation as by that time our troops, advancing overland, would be almost level with the island and on rath June I asked whether the forces earmarked for Elba could not rather be used for a landing on the’ mainland in support of Fifth Army. However, this was considered unacceptable as the French would not consent to the use in Italy of ‘g Colonial Infantry Division, which they wanted to keep for the landings in France. The operation therefore went in as planned in the early morning of 17th June; the occupation of the island was complete by the afternoon of the roth. Steps were taken to emplace medium guns in the north-eastern corner of the island to command Piombino but the town fell on 25th June without the necessity for their use.

events.title: Operation Timing: Target Date Set for May 25 as Enemy Focus Shifts South
events.description: for various reasons, it would be impossible to launch the attack before May and 25th May was choserl_as the target date. This considerably teduced the value of the operation as there was reason to hope that by that date enemy coastal traffic south of Elba would be diminished by reason of our overland advance and he would not be likely to pay much attention to a threat to his tight flank when he knew that all our strength was committed on the southern front.

events.title: Major-General Eastwood Takes Command of Canal Defenses as Improvised Forces Are Dissolved
events.description: On the same day, I issued orders to dissolve the various improvised forces on the Canal line, and their units were absorbed by the formations in the areas of which they now were. I appointed Major-General Eastwood} to take command of the defences on the Canal line, and he assumed command early on 25th May.

events.title: General Thorne Strengthens Defense at Dunkirk by Mobilizing 144th Infantry Brigade to Bergues
events.description: places on 25th May, but General Thorne found that the French had-already made complete dispositions for Dunkirk, and had informed the British Base Commandant. He therefore decided to send 144th Infantry Brigade to Bergues and Wormhoudt. He established his H.Q. at Bergues, which herightly regarded as the vital point of defence.

events.title: French Forces Seize British Posts on River Aa, Activate Dunkirk Flood Defenses
events.description: On the 24th and 25th May the British posts on the river Aa were taken over by the French, who also began to operate the inundations, which formed part of the defence scheme of Dunkirk and extended each side of Bergues and as far as the Belgian frontier north of the Bergues—Furnes canal.

events.title: May 25th: Relentless Strikes on Canal Line and Belgian Forces Disrupt Peace
events.description: 25th May—Aitacks on the Canal Line and on the Belgian Army.

events.title: May 25th: Enemy Forces Ramp Up Assaults Around Denain-Bouchain, Threaten Strategic Canal Positions
events.description: 42, On 25th May, enemy activity intensified. Two enemy Corps were reported to be attacking the French in the area Denain—Bouchain ; the enemy was also across the canal at St. Venant, and was developing the bridgeheads between that place and Aire and also at St. Omer, whilst further north the situation on the river Aa was still obscure...

events.title: Shock Assault: Enemy Forces Breach Belgian Lines with Major Tank Offensive
events.description: At about 7 a.m. on 25th May, news was received that in the late evening of 24th May the enemy had attacked the Belgian 4th Corps on the Lys with a force reported to be of four divisions, supported by tanks. The attack penetrated to a depth of 14 miles on a front of 13 miles between Menin and Desselghem.

events.title: Major-General Eastwood Takes Command as Forces Reorganized Along Canal Line
events.description: On the same day, I issued orders to dissolve the various improvised forces on the Canal line, and their units were absorbed by the formations in the areas of which they now were. I appointed Major-General Eastwood} to take command of the defences on the Canal line, and he assumed command early on 25th May.

events.title: General Thorne Reinforces Bergues as Critical Defense Point Amidst French Preparations for Dunkirk
events.description: places on 25th May, but General Thorne found that the French had-already made complete dispositions for Dunkirk, and had informed the British Base Commandant. He therefore decided to send 144th Infantry Brigade to Bergues and Wormhoudt. He established his H.Q. at Bergues, which herightly regarded as the vital point of defence.

events.title: French Forces Capture British Posts on River Aa, Implement Strategic Inundations Near Dunkirk
events.description: On the 24th and 25th May the British posts on the river Aa were taken over by the French, who also began to operate the inundations, which formed part of the defence scheme of Dunkirk and extended each side of Bergues and as far as the Belgian frontier north of the Bergues—Furnes canal.

events.title: May 25th: Fierce Attacks Erupt on Canal Line, Targeting Belgian Forces
events.description: 25th May—Aitacks on the Canal Line and on the Belgian Army.

events.title: May 25th: Enemy Forces Surge as Dual Corps Assault French Lines Near Denain
events.description: 42, On 25th May, enemy activity intensified. Two enemy Corps were reported to be attacking the French in the area Denain—Bouchain ; the enemy was also across the canal at St. Venant, and was developing the bridgeheads between that place and Aire and also at St. Omer, whilst further north the situation on the river Aa was still obscure...

events.title: Major Assault: Enemy Forces Strike Belgian 4th Corps on Lys, Advancing 14 Miles
events.description: At about 7 a.m. on 25th May, news was received that in the late evening of 24th May the enemy had attacked the Belgian 4th Corps on the Lys with a force reported to be of four divisions, supported by tanks. The attack penetrated to a depth of 14 miles on a front of 13 miles between Menin and Desselghem.

events.description: On the same day, I issued orders to dissolve the various improvised forces on the Canal line, and their units were absorbed by the formations in the areas of which they now were. I appointed Major-General Eastwood} to take command of the defences on the Canal line, and he assumed command early on 25th May.

events.title: General Thorne Strategically Positions Infantry Brigade to Secure Key Defense at Bergues Amidst French Preparations for Dunkirk
events.description: places on 25th May, but General Thorne found that the French had-already made complete dispositions for Dunkirk, and had informed the British Base Commandant. He therefore decided to send 144th Infantry Brigade to Bergues and Wormhoudt. He established his H.Q. at Bergues, which herightly regarded as the vital point of defence.

events.description: 25th May—Aitacks on the Canal Line and on the Belgian Army.

Two enemy Corps were reported to be attacking the French in the area Denain—Bouchain ; the enemy was also across the canal at St. Venant, and was developing the bridgeheads between that place and Aire and also at St. Omer, whilst further north the situation on the river Aa was still obscure...

The attack penetrated to a depth of 14 miles on a front of 13 miles between Menin and Desselghem.

I appointed Major-General Eastwood} to take command of the defences on the Canal line, and he assumed command early on 25th May.

He therefore decided to send 144th Infantry Brigade to Bergues and Wormhoudt. He established his H.Q. at Bergues, which herightly regarded as the vital point of defence.

events.description: 25th May—Aitacks on the Canal Line and on the Belgian Army.

Two enemy Corps were reported to be attacking the French in the area Denain—Bouchain ; the enemy was also across the canal at St. Venant, and was developing the bridgeheads between that place and Aire and also at St. Omer, whilst further north the situation on the river Aa was still obscure...

events.title: Major Enemy Offensive Strikes Belgian 4th Corps, Penetrates 14 Miles Amid Tank Assault
events.description: At about 7 a.m. on 25th May, news was received that in the late evening of 24th May the enemy had attacked the Belgian 4th Corps on the Lys with a force reported to be of four divisions, supported by tanks. The attack penetrated to a depth of 14 miles on a front of 13 miles between Menin and Desselghem.

events.title: Command Restructured: Major-General Eastwood Takes Charge of Canal Line Defenses
events.description: On the same day, I issued orders to dissolve the various improvised forces on the Canal line, and their units were absorbed by the formations in the areas of which they now were. I appointed Major-General Eastwood} to take command of the defences on the Canal line, and he assumed command early on 25th May.

events.title: General Thorne Strategizes Defense as French Prepare for Dunkirk
events.description: places on 25th May, but General Thorne found that the French had-already made complete dispositions for Dunkirk, and had informed the British Base Commandant. He therefore decided to send 144th Infantry Brigade to Bergues and Wormhoudt. He established his H.Q. at Bergues, which herightly regarded as the vital point of defence.

events.title: French Forces Seize British Posts on River Aa, Activate Dunkirk Defense Strategy
events.description: On the 24th and 25th May the British posts on the river Aa were taken over by the French, who also began to operate the inundations, which formed part of the defence scheme of Dunkirk and extended each side of Bergues and as far as the Belgian frontier north of the Bergues—Furnes canal.

events.title: May 25th: Canal Line Under Siege as Belgian Army Faces Aggressive Attacks
events.description: 25th May—Aitacks on the Canal Line and on the Belgian Army.

events.title: May 25: Enemy Forces Launch Coordinated Attacks Across Northern France
events.description: 42, On 25th May, enemy activity intensified. Two enemy Corps were reported to be attacking the French in the area Denain—Bouchain ; the enemy was also across the canal at St. Venant, and was developing the bridgeheads between that place and Aire and also at St. Omer, whilst further north the situation on the river Aa was still obscure...

events.title: Enemy Forces Launch Coordinated Attack on Belgian 4th Corps, Breaching 14 Miles into Allied Lines
events.description: At about 7 a.m. on 25th May, news was received that in the late evening of 24th May the enemy had attacked the Belgian 4th Corps on the Lys with a force reported to be of four divisions, supported by tanks. The attack penetrated to a depth of 14 miles on a front of 13 miles between Menin and Desselghem.

events.title: Major-General Eastwood Takes Command as Improvised Forces Dissolved Along Canal Line
events.description: On the same day, I issued orders to dissolve the various improvised forces on the Canal line, and their units were absorbed by the formations in the areas of which they now were. I appointed Major-General Eastwood} to take command of the defences on the Canal line, and he assumed command early on 25th May.

events.title: General Thorne Strategically Positions Troops in Critical Defense of Dunkirk
events.description: places on 25th May, but General Thorne found that the French had-already made complete dispositions for Dunkirk, and had informed the British Base Commandant. He therefore decided to send 144th Infantry Brigade to Bergues and Wormhoudt. He established his H.Q. at Bergues, which herightly regarded as the vital point of defence.

events.title: French Forces Seize British Posts and Activate Dunkirk's Defenses Amidst Rising Tensions
events.description: On the 24th and 25th May the British posts on the river Aa were taken over by the French, who also began to operate the inundations, which formed part of the defence scheme of Dunkirk and extended each side of Bergues and as far as the Belgian frontier north of the Bergues—Furnes canal.

events.title: May 25th: Canal Line Under Siege as Belgian Forces Face Assault
events.description: 25th May—Aitacks on the Canal Line and on the Belgian Army.

events.title: Enemy Forces Ramp Up Assault in Denain-Bouchain Region as Threat Grows Across Canal
events.description: 42, On 25th May, enemy activity intensified. Two enemy Corps were reported to be attacking the French in the area Denain—Bouchain ; the enemy was also across the canal at St. Venant, and was developing the bridgeheads between that place and Aire and also at St. Omer, whilst further north the situation on the river Aa was still obscure...

events.title: Enemy Assaults Belgian 4th Corps: Four Divisions and Tanks Strike Deep on the Lys
events.description: At about 7 a.m. on 25th May, news was received that in the late evening of 24th May the enemy had attacked the Belgian 4th Corps on the Lys with a force reported to be of four divisions, supported by tanks. The attack penetrated to a depth of 14 miles on a front of 13 miles between Menin and Desselghem.

events.title: Sir John Dill Warns: Counter-Attack Ineffective as Enemy Breaches Belgian Defences
events.description: Sir John Dill (who had now become C.I.G.S.) and whom I had asked to visit me, ‘arrived on the morning of 25th May, and I explained the pesson to him. He then telegraphed to the rime Minister and to the Secretary of State, that there could be no disguising the seriousness of the situation. He added that in his opinion the proposed counter-attack to the south could not be an important affair in view of the enemy attacks which had penetrated the Belgian defences. .

events.title: Brave Divisions Hold the Line at Ypres Since May 25th
events.description: These two divisions had been in the line at ‘Ypres since 25th May. They had held positions

events.title: Allied Forces Set Sights on Akyab and Ramree Island Amidst Key Offensive Planning in South East Asia
events.description: At the Washington Conference of 12th to 25th May, 1943, it was resolved to capture Akyab and Ramree Island by an amphibious operation; also, possibly, to exploit any success gained. This was part of the general pattern of offensive operations in the South. East Asia Theatre, and plans were being formulated accordingly, It will be remembered, however, that at this time first priority on our resources was still allocated to the air ferry to China.

events.title: Indian Troops Overcome Fierce Resistance to Capture Strategic Thandaung Junction
events.description: 19 Indian Division from Toungoo had by the 10th May advanced 5 miles along the road to Thandaung, but 98 Brigade, the leaders, were being strenuously opposed. On this date 62 Brigade, with tank support, took over the lead and fought its way forward in the face of extensive mining of the road and determined. resistance from prepared positions on the high ground dominating the area. On the 25th May 98 Brigade took over again, and three days later captured the road junction at Thandaung,

events.title: Joyous Reception: Troops Occupy Bassein Amid Unopposed Takeover
events.description: 280. Bassein was occupied by a battalion group of 6 Brigade without opposition on the 25th May, our troops receiving a joyous welcome from the local inhabitants.

events.title: Indian Division Battles Through Opposition to Capture Key Thandaung Junction
events.description: 19 Indian Division from Toungoo had by the 10th May advanced 5 miles along the road to Thandaung, but 98 Brigade, the leaders, were being strenuously opposed. On this date 62 Brigade, with tank support, took over the lead and fought its way forward in the face of extensive mining of the road and determined. resistance from prepared positions on the high ground dominating the area. On the 25th May 98 Brigade took over again, and three days later captured the road junction at Thandaung,

events.title: Bassein Welcomes Troops: 6 Brigade Occupies City Without Resistance
events.description: 280. Bassein was occupied by a battalion group of 6 Brigade without opposition on the 25th May, our troops receiving a joyous welcome from the local inhabitants.
